By Ceph conventions, the name of the file is ${cluster_name}.conf. So far we have allowed only for the default cluster, canonically named "ceph". I need to update the commit contents, but what was agreed with the previous reviewer was creating a new <config>/cinder/ceph/ directory where all ceph conf files can be placed, regardless of name.

The legacy ceph.conf file is still being handled in the same way as before, so old deployments should work correctly.

Added a new variable `ceph_conf_files` where the names of conf files must be declared for them to be copied. 

I think using the `cinder/ceph/` directory is helpful to maintain order, so this variable must hold a list of the name of the ceph conf files present in said directory. So if the variable is declared like this:

ceph_conf_files: ["ceph-ec.conf", "ceph-ec-secondpool.conf", "ceph-ec-thirdpool.conf"]

The directory should look this way:

{{ node_custom_config }}
└──cinder
    └── ceph
        ├── ceph-ec.conf
        ├── ceph-ec-secondpool.conf
        └── ceph-ec-thirdpool.conf

Left a default value to handle legacy ceph.conf files.

I know it was, but if we do it this way - we'll end up with the issue that I pointed out in config.json file review - and personally I like to have ceph.confs named, instead of doing them numbered (like ceph-ec.conf, ceph-ec-secondpool.conf, instead of ceph1.conf ceph2.conf which are a bit meaningless unless you look inside).

https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/7e033ef23a7f45b58056a73b3834fa68/log/primary/logs/ansible/test-core-openstack#638

While the task is searching inside {{ node_custom_config }}/cinder/ceph/, the default value of ceph_conf_files considers this and contains the path of the ceph.conf file relative to this directory.

If we assume existing deployments won't use the ceph_conf_files variable, the default value will take over which is a list only containing "../ceph.conf", the task will copy `{{ node_custom_config }}/cinder/ceph/../ceph.conf` == `{{ node_custom_config }}/cinder/ceph.conf`. I do not understand. This phrase makes no sense. Did you mean "why we order by deleted and the project_id" or ...?
I meant "why we order by deleted and then project_id", will fix it.
Is it just me, of the  table volumes has redundant indexes attached (same key, only cardinality is different)? Please be gentle and tell me "no", I don't know anything about databases.

I'm no expert either.  ;-)

If you look even if the key is the same the key_name is also different.

So here we see column name "deleted" for the volumes table for both the "volumes_service_uuid_idx" and the "volumes_deleted_project_id_idx" indexes.

That's because these are composite indexes and not just single indexes, so one index uses ('service_uuid', deleted') and the other ('deleted', 'project_id').  Both have the deleted column, but they are different btrees, and the old index we had didn't even help queries using deleted in the filter (which are most of them) because it was the second field...

What do you think the impact of new indexes is going to be for insertions? Or do we list volumes much more often than create them?

I think the number of times we create/delete resources is usually significantly lower than the times these are queried in the different operations, and if we add the fact that we currently have to go through all the deleted rows and rows for other projects that means that Cinder has a scaling problem.

I think these indexes are useful, but I'm open to discussing them on a per-index basis if you think some may not be that useful.

glance_store/_drivers/cinder/store.py.message:
So this would be yet another configuration option, which would need to be set by the admins (or by the installer).

Is there any reason why an admin would choose not to enable this option if it is available? If this is something that we *always* want to turn on (when it's available, of course) then shouldn't we autodetect that the Cinder backend can perform the extension?

The problem with "always" enabling it is if the cinder volume driver doesn't support extending attached volumes, it will raise an exception and cinder will put the volume in unusable state. For e.g., In cinder NFS driver, if we call extend API to extend in-use volume, it raises ExtendVolumeError[1] which cinder catches and changes the volume status to "error_extending" [2] i.e. making it unusable.

There is no way to know if a driver can perform the extend volume operation for attached volumes unless we actually perform that operation but it can cause the volume to be inaccessible, as mentioned above, so we only want to perform this unless we're 100% sure the driver can perform this for which we're introducing this new config option.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/f11ff244b78f5d353cfc8c06c21adf63d2f2c5a1/cinder/volume/drivers/nfs.py#L377
[2] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/f11ff244b78f5d353cfc8c06c21adf63d2f2c5a1/cinder/volume/manager.py#L2967-L2968

any reason why you're not following your public interface with create() and save() ?

See, I'm quite unhappy with the existing interfaces you created.

What I'd prefer is to follow the same pattern we have for other objects : 
1/ we have object methods for creating, updating and deleting objects
2/ we can persist the object by a specific save() method.
3/ if a method modifies an object field, it can call save() to persist the modification into the DB.

That way, we can use an object and modify it directly without needing it to be persisted, unless we want to.

No, you shouldn't be doing it this way. I don't know yet which service will call .mount() of that object, but I guess this is the API. If so, the API should rather call the compute RPC API with a mount() RPC call by passing the object as a paramter, rather than doing it this way.

This can cause a serious behavior change in nova.

This will make the number of green threads bounded (to 1000 by default). In the baseline nova was able to run as many greenlet as it wished (and fit into memory). So while before leaking a defunct (i.e. forever sleeping) greenlet caused a small memory leak now it can cause a blockage in nova processing if we running out of the free greenlets in the pool. As the default number of greenlets are high we won't see such blockage in our test but can hit it in production in long running deployments. 

So we need to be careful.

Maybe we need to add some debug log in a periodic about the number of free greenlets in the pool and check that logs in a tempest run to see if the number of used greenlets are stable or increasing.
at least RPC handler from oslo.messaging is not using our nova.utils functions so all our RPC handlers will be outside of this pool so if a test leaks that then it won't be caught here.

Thanks for the contribution. I didn't make devstack run on Centos 9 Stream, although there are packages for a bit newer kubernetes available[1], so my point still stands. Especially, that there is already configurable option to change the cri-o version on settings. What I'm suggesting is to use $os_VENDOR/$os_RELEASE to determine right Centos version. Something like this should work:

```
if [[ "${os_VENDOR}" == *'Stream' ]]; then
    local stream="_Stream"
fi
sudo yum-config-manager \
  --add-repo \
  "https://download.opensuse.org/repositories/"`
  `"devel:/kubic:/libcontainers:/stable:/cri-o:/${CRIO_VERSION}/"`
  `"CentOS_${os_RELEASE}${stream}/"
```

[1] https://download.opensuse.org/repositories/devel:/kubic:/libcontainers:/stable:/cri-o:/1.26/CentOS_9_Stream/

Well, it will work with Centos Stream 9 and CRIO_VERSION=1.26, no? Hardcoding version instead of using ability to detect it by devstack will just make another person to patch this up just to bump Centos Stream to 9, and than 10, and so on. I'd like to avoid such situation and give an options for others who want to try this with newer version of operating system.

In your case, when you use Centos Stream 8 it will works exactly like you want to, so the adding repository for the correct version of the Centos (i.e. 
```
https://download.opensuse.org/repositories/devel:/kubic:/libcontainers:/stable:/cri-o:/1.25/CentOS_8_Stream/
```
While on newer stream version it will become (assuming, you'll have set CRIO_VERSION to 1.26 in settings):
```
https://download.opensuse.org/repositories/devel:/kubic:/libcontainers:/stable:/cri-o:/1.26/CentOS_9_Stream/
```
Or, is there something else, which prevents you from following that pattern?

Thanks for review comments.
Comment incorporated; Currently CentOS Stream 9 has no valid repo for crio because of that can not make it parametrized based upon OS.
Currently we have considered CentOS_8_Stream crio repo.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
I am not -1, but I have reservations.  

* This is only image based.  I think if we are starting this fresh, I would prefer to see this based on containerfile, as that seems a better way going forward.  I imagine rocky has some sort of container image that could pull from.  

* We have a lot of "if DISTRO=centos" places that this doesn't cover.  One in particular is in glean, where this isn't using the NetworkManager path because it doesn't match any of that.  There is probably other things lying around all over like that.  

* This seems self contained -- but then if we follow the point above it starts becoming less self-contained.  This is always a maintenance burden and we have to honestly trade-off how many resources we have available.

* We've accepted OpenEuler, a counterpoint to some of the above points

What are the practical plans for this?  Is the goal for this to end up as an OpenDev base platform?  Who is interested?

> I'll look into basing that on container file - are there any examples that I should follow?

we are currently using

https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/src/branch/master/diskimage_builder/elements/fedora-container

in production to build fedora images

We have no used image-based builds, that start with the upstream .qcow2, in OpenDev production for quite some time.  The reason is that we found the upstream images tended to change in ways that constantly broke production, especially since they tend to include potentially a lot of things pre-installed.

This is why we use the "-minimal" images.  However, these build using rpm to extract a base chroot -- this can also have it's own issues.

We feel that containerfile is a good medium.  We expect the container images to be absolutely minimal, and also to not change very much at all.  So by using them as an initial chroot environment we get the best of both worlds, as it were.

> Practical plan is to use this as OpenDev base platform (OpenStack Kolla has a plan to add support for Rocky Linux 8) - if that's something that would be accepted.

I feel this is something worth running past a wider audience than this change.  If we are building things and supporting 8-stream -- it feels like this implies that things will work on rocky which is aimed at trailing that.  Maintaining a platform in OpenDev is not *that* hard, but there's only so much bandwidth

Thanks, you might be right it might just too much of a burden to maintain those images in opendev CI - just to get through Kolla-Ansible host prechecks (that check Ansible distribution facts).
But anyway - I'll rework this change to use containerfile (because we - StackHPC rely on diskimage-builder to build the images for actual deployments).

I'll look into basing that on container file - are there any examples that I should follow?
Practical plan is to use this as OpenDev base platform (OpenStack Kolla has a plan to add support for Rocky Linux 8) - if that's something that would be accepted.
Let's continue in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/diskimage-builder/+/825957

Thank you for creating this new element, Jing, Michal,and Manuel! I left a few comments inline. If you decide to move this to a container-based format, then you can probably disregard these comments. :-)

I agree with Ian's points on maintenance burden and usage of test resources. Personally, I really like the idea of supporting non-Stream CentOS alternative distributions such as Rocky. I see a trend in OpenStack to switch to CentOS Stream, but from a community perspective, AlmaLinux OS and Rocky Linux have gained a lot of traction lately.

We have interest from an openstack-ansible contributor to support Rocky Linux, though we have not decided yet as a team if this is something we want to commit to in OSA.

Having these images would be something that OSA would need if we moved forward with Rocky Linux support.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Can backporting this break existing deployments?

Existing event_definitions.yamls won't get cleaned up and the "orphaned" one already inside the container will be used preferentially to the one shipped with Ceilometer if there's no override file. This means that existing deployments without an override shouldn't end up any more broken than they already are. Deployments with an override should be unaffected.

I could add a task to clean up "orphaned" files if there's no override supplied?

manila_tempest_tests/tests/rbac/test_sna.message:
hmmm, this should still be forbidden - the API isn't available to non-admins by default:

Our RBAC enforcement happens in stages:
1) Do you have access to the API
2) Do you have access to the resource
3) Do you have access to perform the API on the resource

If (1) fails, you get a 403 always, 
if (2) fails, you get a 404; 
if (3) fails, you get a 403. 

More often than not, (2) will prevent "existence" detection of resources that don't belong to the user; except in case of "public" resources (e.g.: shares can be "public")

Thank you for the clarification!
I wasn't sure about that.
It makes sense.

I reported a bug on it on both upstream and downstream.
I'll close them.

ansible/library/kolla_docker.py.message:
This suggests common_options takes precedence over module parameters? That seems wrong to me.

The precedence should be:

provided module arguments > common options > module parameter defaults

I think the problem with the current logic is that if a parameter default is not None, then it overrides any common options.

Probably the "correct" way to do this is using module defaults https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/playbook_guide/playbooks_module_defaults.html. It would make site.yml more verbose though.

> Hmm, that sounds nice, but then we can drop common options, can't we ?

It could be dropped from module arguments, yes.

> This will be XL patchset ... I really don't like it ..i better fix the logic in kolla_docker.py file ..what do you think ?

Is that using module_defaults for every module? If we just do it to fix this issue it should be 2 extra lines per play, and lots of single line common_options argument removals.

I'm open to a python fix, I just couldn't see how to do it in a "nice" way when there are defaults that are not None.

tests/test_kolla_docker.py.message: Is there an option we don't copy this from the original code?

No, that's the basic idea of writing a unit tests. Unit tests has to work the same way as the original code, and original code is same as unit test.

If you are asking for module.params = copy.deepcopy(mod_param) , this is only  because mod_param is parameter ..not object as in kolla docker worker python script.

If you will not use copy.deepcopy ..code below is changing mod_param directly even if you assigned to module.params. Python is using reference.
is there an option we don't reply this over three functions with hardcoded values (you already have the values defined earlier)?

But every function is doing something different:

Test_common_options_defaults -> is testing if module (without defined module's parameter common_options) has defaults (as they were removed from module paameters defaults - but moved to dict with defaults).

test_common_options - is testing if module with common_options parameter defined (with *different values* than default) match different values in params 

Here assert can be changed to mapping to FAKE_DATA_COMMON_OPTS, if they are same.

test_common_options_overriden - this is test if parameter has priority before common_options.

Implementation lgtm.

However this will cause a lot more requests to the api/tenants endpoint. This currently is in zuul-web not optimized as it is uncached and iterates over all tenants and pipelines to gather queue statistics. Especially on large systems with many tenants and pipelines this can add significant extra load on zuul-web. Thus this needs to be optimized via caching similar to the status endpoint before we can merge this change.

Maybe we could enhance the /tenants endpoint to only provide the list of tenant names (by adding a get parameter like `names_only`) or add a new endpoint for this. Currently, the costly part of the /tenants endpoint is iterating over all pipelines to get the length of the queues (which iterates directly over the ZooKeeper data structure). However, for a functionality like this, the tenant names would be sufficient (which are looked up from the local abide object in zuul-web directly, so that doesn't involve any ZooKeeper operations).

With both in place (tenant names endpoint and tenant dropdown) we could further reduce the amount of requests to the tenants/ endpoint as a user doesn't need to visit the tenants page to simply switch tenants.
This is now rebased on top of 832293 which adds caching for the tenants endpoint.

That was my original plan, see: https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/832258

I liked the caching approach seen in this present patch because it had a minimal impact on the GUI, ie no need to handle cases in the redux engine when to use names_only or not, or to have a new entry in the redux store for tenants only. I'd have to rework 810955 quite a bit if I were to rebase on top of 832258.

We could also handle caching at the GUI level, add an option to fetchTenantsIfNeeded to not call the API if tenants info is already in the store when invoked by the tenants dropdown component - if it is possible at all.

That's now 3 different approaches for this feature, so I'd appreciate a definitive opinion before going further with it. :)
Fine for me as is with the now implemented caching of /tenants

so does this mean that rbd will have items in this trash bin occupying space that cinder can't then control and delete?  Will there be a discrepancy with the reported free space vs what cinder has allocated?

When does this trash get emptied if ever?

IF there is space occupied and there is no way for an operator to clean it up, that wouldn't be nice either, especially if as an operator I'd want to drain a particular pool and move things elsewhere, or are getting full on space, but there is hidden space being occupied that cinder can't clean out.

Usage of the trash for deletion is already a Cinder RBD feature, and Cinder can periodically purge the trash (configuration options enable_deferred_deletion, deferred_deletion_delay, and deferred_deletion_purge_interval).

Depending on the Ceph version, purging can also be scheduled on the Ceph cluster itself, and iirc an operator can actually purge a specific image in the trash manually as well.

I will update just based on the technical aspect from an operators view.

This makes a lot of sense, for us personally this would not incur any additional processing because we already flatten volumes created from snapshots, so we already do capacity planning based on actual usage since we potentially lose a little bit of storage doing that.

But I agree that this should be the default behaviour because it's annoying when you cannot delete the snapshot because it's been cloned from to a new volume.

The ratelimit part is I think very important, but I have a question, has it been considered to have this behaviour configurable but still be enabled by default?

I can see people that does not want to flatten, or that has a very tight restriction on storage usage getting potential problems.

I think it's a bit of an anti-pattern to make a hook wait 15 minutes for something to happen in the cloud.  Is this more of:

a) It's going to work in < 5m or never?
b) It's something we have to retry if it failed, say 5 mins later.

If it's a) then this time ought to be reduced.  If b) then I'd switch it to blocked after say a couple of mins, and then retry the process in the next hook (likely to be update-status), or via an action, although the action doesn't sound good.  Maybe it just needs another toggle on the management port or something similar; I realise that this is papering over existing faults, but it seems better than just waiting for 15 mins?
Ack

The whole challenge here is that the existing code of the `configure-resource` action doesn't ensure that asynchronous steps are completed before moving to configure something. i.e. step 1 and 2 must be sequential but doesn't wait between 1&2.

1. creating a router and a port in Neutron to enable SLAAC (on neutron db)
2. the actual port gets an IPv6 address and it's to be read and written to octavia.conf (on the actual octavia units)

More details are in the linked bug report:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/charm-octavia/+bug/1961088

> a) It's going to work in < 5m or never?

For Ussuri, it should be okay as <5m or never. For Wallaby/Xena/Yoga, it may take up to 10 min to get RA after sending out RS to wait for the default RA interval:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/charm-ovn-chassis/+bug/1965883

But in both cases, we cay say it's < 15m or never. To be precise 11m or 12m should be fine as well but we never know precisely how many seconds it would take to send RA after writing necessary resources to neutron db.


> next hook (likely to be update-status)

This is an option but I suppose we shouldn't be writing octavia.conf in an update-status hook.

> via an action, although the action doesn't sound good.

Yeah, this part of the code is already in the `configure-resource` action. So it would be awkward to have `configure-resources` and `wait-resources` as separate actions. Also, we have to wait in the `wait-resources` anyway so it doesn't have much difference from waiting in `configure-resources` itself.


This is already complicated so I suggested Samuel to do retries in this part of the code for simplicity.

Ah, my bad; I'd forgotten this code path was part of an action and not a hook.  That changes things substantially, and I think the 15 mins wait is acceptable.  If it's taking a while, I think it would be perfectly acceptable to update the status message directly (e.g. if an op is watching the juju status) during the retries, and then calling the update_status handler at the end to set it to the 'current' status.

Note to reviewers: most logging here was added to aid debugging - we'll probably want these removed or modified before merging.  Any comments about what kind of logging would be useful with these additions would be appreciated.

As a general note on logging, from an operations POV more logging is better (with appropriate log levels set), ideally also with system data (such as ipaddrs, see comment above in `is_address_on_mgmt_interface()`) and details e.g. the number of tries done
I think a log message or success or failure at the end of the waiting period is probably most appropriate at the INFO level.  These logs should probably be at the DEBUG level.

So the idea is to add a "rebuild_configdrive" RPC-method that requires a certain RPC version. That's much cleaner, I totally agree.

Just one question remains: Where to store / how to handle the new user_data while the "update_userdata" action is not done? (see previous discussion: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/816157/comments/033c59ff_53cd6b34).

1. Should we send it via RPC to the agent then rebuilding the config_drive and on success update the user_data in the database and set the action to "successful"?

2. Or should we just attach the action ID via RPC to the agent and rather have it "fetch" the userdata from the action?

well the specific RPC call is the new one that is intoduced for this instance action so i think we are all in agreement that option 1 is the path to take.

on the api side fi the compute node is two old the rpc call will fail so that provides the protection we require to mark the instance action as failed and ensure the state in the db is not modifed.
That was my understanding as well, to not create a "shadow RPC" call in this manner.

Here the context from Dan is to make sure we can ping the nova-compute service by RPC for knowing whether it can recreate the configdrive.

This is not really a concern on how to save the modified userdata. So, while I agree with gibi here on the fact an instance.save() is enough to persist the modification, we still need to make sure we can have a specific RPC call for it.

we have 2 options

either the payload of the new instance action can be the content of the new userdtata which we can pass via rpc to the comptue which will update it in the db and regenerate teh confgi drive.


or  the new action should take no payload adn just triger the config drive to be regenerated from the current metadata.

so i think option 1 include the data in the rpc and commit it to the db from the compute.

that a bit inefficent but it proably is the more consitent way to do this.

your option 2 will not work as there is no way for the agent to "fetch" the userdata form the action.
we woudl jsut need the new action start and end notification for this
Done
at the compute agent perhaps but the work flow at the api should be identical.
Yep, will update the wording here.

im not sure if we need this complexity.

how are you going to know if the instnqace is using config drive.

are you going to check the instance system metadata to see if the vm is booted with config drive.

this is an option but it would requrie two code path to update the userdata.

its proably better to just alway make the rpc call passing the user-data
but have the compute agent skip regenerating the config drive if the vms does not have a config drive.

I agree that it's more work to do the configdrive thing. It seems nice from the user's perspective, but I'm not sure it's really worth it. Instances using config drives could also be looking at the metadata server, and it would be unfortunate to force those to go through a reboot cycle just to make the API call work.

Yes, the thought was to query the instance's system metadata to check whether it uses a config drive, like in the initial implementation.

Complexity-wise, I agree that it would be cleaner to just have one code path for that. If there are no implications with calling the RPC method every time (e. g. performance, dependence on RPC / updated agents), and no one else disagrees, I guess I can update the spec accordingly.

I think what I'd prefer is to just set a flag that the compute manager will check on next boot. Like, we could shove a flag into system_metadata that says "config drive is dirty". Then whenever we go to start an instance, we check that flag and regenerate like we normally would on hard reboot, initial boot, or whatever.

Doing it in the context of an RPC call means it needs to complete within the timeout of an http (and rpc) call. Also, unless you provide a lock to prevent it from happening more than once, you could be adding a sort of DoS attack vector for the user to take against the compute.

Setting the flag and letting it be regenerated on next boot puts like activities together.

Ok, that makes sense.

So the proposal would be to still use a flag (like config_drive_dirty in the initial implementation) and additionally check during the HTTP call if the RPC version of the compute host that instance is currently living on is new enough. We would still require instances to be stopped. Whenever the instance is started again, compute driver checks the flag and regenerates config drive if True. To my understanding, this approach would basically replace the last step in the spec's current version.

Since this is yet another approach that differs from what we agreed on after Zed's feature freeze, I would be happy to hear other opinions on this @Sean @gibi @Sylvain.

What I said is that if we're going to do it as part of the reboot, it needs to be a flag to the RPC call so that we're not subverting the RPC interface's versioning scheme, effectively making a call we expect to have certain characteristics not represented by the version we asked for, not knowing if the other side is actually new enough or not. That's the thing I was concerned about there.

Making a *new* synchronous RPC call that must do substantial IO on the destination machine within the timeout of an HTTP request (and the MQ timeout for that matter) is also problematic for other reasons, as described above.

If you use a flag on the instance, which has the implication on "next boot" then we do not need to make the synchronous call. The flag is also not specifically related to any RPC call that fails to cover it in the versioning scheme, so we're not subverting that. Finally, you can check the service version of the host the instance is on (and yes, bump it for this feature) to make sure that it will honor it at next boot before you tell the HTTP requester that "yes, I will schedule that to be done."

Correct me if I'm wrong, but wasn't that your proposal to use RPCs in the first place (https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova-specs/+/863884/1..6/specs/2023.1/approved/update-userdata.rst#100)? Could you further elaborate on this?

By "regenerate like we normally would" you mean calling already existing methods? So we would not need to create a new RPC method just for config drive regen?

I chose to not diverge from the existing design pattern, where every service is presumed to have a network. We know tripleo-ansible includes every service in its loop, regardless of whether there's an entry in the ServiceNetMap. The glance_api_internal_node_ips and _names will appear in /etc/puppet/hieradata/all_nodes.json, regardless of whether there's a ServiceNetMap entry. Overriding the values results in additional entries in service_configs.json. The variables appear twice in the hieradata, which doesn't feel right and is potentially confusing to anyone not familiar with the design.

Also, the two services don't even have to be on the same network, it's just that tripleo uses the internal_api for many of them.

Sorry it took me a while until I went through the whole implementation and I'm joining this too late.

Regarding the existing override, I think that is dependent on a bit different situation. In edge compute we deploy only glance_api_edge service without glance_api and glance_api_internal. However, to enable haproxy in the edge site, we forcefully enable the endpoint[1] for glance_api_internal (previously, glance_api). This is why we need to override these node_ips or node_names because these are not populated by t-a because glance_api(_internal) service is not enabled in the edge stack. So the main intention of the override is not overriding the network but hijacking the existing implementation for glance_api(_internal) for _edge.

[1]
https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/deployment/haproxy/haproxy-edge-container-puppet.yaml#L94

Now I feel like the solution suggested by Alan would be correct, though we still have a problem. Currently glance-api-internal service is deployed in GlanceApiNetwork, instead of GlanceApiInternalNetwork. This means we technically should use glance_api_node_(ip/name)s instead of glance_api_internal_node_(ip/name)s. If we pursue GlanceApiInternalNetwork then we have to fix that point.

It's true the HAproxyEdge overrides the data, but it does so solely to satisfy unique requirements for DCN/Edge (it's done that way to select a subset of nodes).

I guess we need to leave it up to other reviewers to decide which approach they prefer. If they do choose your override method, then I would ask you remove the bad "GlanceApiEdgeInternalNetwork" entry (the one with my typo) from the ServiceNetMap.

The reason I manage the share again is because after unmanaging operation, the share is removed from the management of the shared file systems service without deleting the share. So in order to be able to delete the share we need to manage it again.

there are some advanatages to useing a systemd service file to do this so we could consider proviing an exmaple of creating one that will run before the libvirt service start but im ok with the udev approch.

i would like you to remove the tripleo isum of /home/heat-admin as i find that rather confusing hence the -1.

i know why you used that example but if i did not have extra context i would find it rather odd.

there is a libvirt feature that might be able to auto recreate it but it would depend on how you have libvirt deployed.

it would not work if you deployed libvirt in a contianer today.
so it would not work for kolla or tripleo
if you create mdevs with the libvirt node-dev api then it will internally call mdevctl and if you set a persitent flag on the mdev then a udev rule packaged with mdevctl will recreate it on host boot.


removing the auto create capablity that we have today would not preclude adding support for that in the future but currently nova has no depency on mdevctl.

as i said this wont work if libvirt/mdevctl are installed in a continer as the udev rule will not be triggered. you would have to install the udev rule on the host and bindmount the directory where the mdev info is stored form the libvirt contaienr to the host so that the udev rule would work.

in generall i think its better to remove our current support for recreating the mdevs and avoid the extra complixity that woudl be required to enable this fucntionality. however once we have done that if you or other want to propose a small feature to port our use to the node-dev api instead of sysfs thats somethign we could disucss futher.

if you do a classic install where libvirt/mdevctl is installed on the host without contaienrs in the way it would be useful. any contaieriesed installer woudl need ot be modifed seperatly to make this work the same way they have to install ceph-common today to provide the udev rule that names the voulme device with the volume uuid.
I understand, thanks for your detailed (as always) response, very appreciated!

doc/source/admin/virtual-gpu.rst.message: I'm not really understanding how/why placement/nova are going to pick one of these pre-created devices? Can UUID of mdev device be just random then, generated with uuidgen? For some reason I thought it should be smth meaningful, like VM UUID.

No worries, the nova driver finds them by calling libvirt to tell us which mediated devices already exist.
Then we compare them with all the domains XML to see which ones are currently bound to an instance or just free to be use.

the uuids used by nova are random today.

they dont have any specific meaning.

we had the desigin choice to make them persitent and stable across host but chose not to to aovid needing to store the info in the db. as such there is no really meaning in the uuid ites self any more the a pci adress has.

its just the identifier we used to map a vm to an mdev.

i think this udev rule will be triggered for all devices?
Additionally, with udev it's hard to manage dependencies between systemd units.

For example we use nvidia cards so we need to execute below steps in a following order during boot:

1. enable virtual functions on nvidia GPUs(i.e `/usr/lib/nvidia/sriov-manage -e %i`, it's handled by nvidia-sriov-manage@.service)
2. create mdev devices(we created 'vgpu-mdev-create.service' systemd service instead of udev rule)
3. start nova-compute


So i think it may be better to suggest using systemd unit instead of udev rule in our docs.
Here you can find our 'vgpu-mdev-create.service' and 'nvidia-sriov-manage@.service' unit definitions: https://paste.openstack.org/show/bU4qYaIySl5y7qEsEWjR/

i would prefer to now include /home/heat-admin here as that is very ooo specific.

the script really should be located somewhere else liek /usr/local/bin or /opt/...

we support generic mdevs so we dont really want to encode vendor speciric info in our docs.

with that said we could perhaps rference this as an example.

swift/proxy/controllers/base.py.message:
IIRC Tim pointed out that caching the lowers AND uppers of each namespace might almost double the size of the cached blob, and the uppers are redundant in the context of a contiguous sequence of namespaces. 

You could drop the uppers when serialising to memcache here (have an sr.dict_namespace_lower method or similar) but then you'd need to figure out the upper when deserialising, in order to construct a ShardRange. That's one of the things the NamespaceMap class in my patch is doing i.e. providing an interface to get Namespaces with (name, lower, and upper) from a list of just (name, lower).
if we're really worried about upgrade (I'm not sure I am) - maybe we could have left the key the same, and made our code robust to read either format (but always writeback the optimized form)
during upgrade older proxies cannot parse the new format if it is stored under the same key

IMHO the method name should communicate what the method accepts, not what the caller chooses to pass in.

I'd have less objection to renaming to something bland like parse(), but I'd dislike renaming to e.g. 'from_shard_ranges()' for the following reasons:

* Future me will always get a good idea of what the method accepts from its name. We may not currently pass in Namespaces, but we *can*, and if the method is called from_shard_ranges then at first glance it suggests that we *cannot* pass in just Namespaces.

* The method docstring is consistent with its name (oops, we don't have a docstring on this method yet!). Do we change the arg name to 'shard_ranges', but then document it as being a list of Namespaces? that doesn't stack up.

* If in future a caller ever chooses to pass in a list of Namespaces then we don't have to consider changing the method name (from_shard_ranges -> from_namespaces) to adapt to the caller's whims.

What I'd like is to have polymorphic constructors 😄 I did consider having the constructor accept either bounds or Namespaces, then type-testing and doing the right-thing.
we don't need this to be a ShardRange except for the 'name' parsing to account/container

designate_tempest_plugin/tests/scenario/.message:
Ok, this test is setup wrong. Per the RFC[1] the maximum size of a DNS label is 63 characters.

The test, as it is current written creates a label of 251 characters.
So, the API is actually rejecting this create call before it even gets to the zone name length check.

This test will need to be updated to build up the zone name to the maximum character length in 63 or less characters per label.

[1] https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc1035#section-2.3.4

OK, got it.
Will be fixed in the next patchset.
Thanks Michael!

Hi Michael!

Yep, that's correct and I've also seen that the limit is somewhere about 6X while trying to find the reason of tests' failure.

In fact, this test is just trying to use 254 characters because this is the actual limit number for: max_zone_name_length returned from the Designate (see L38) is 255: 
cls.project_limits is:
{'max_zones': 10, 'max_zone_recordsets': 500, 'max_zone_records': 500, 'max_recordset_records': 20, 'min_ttl': None, 'max_zone_name_length': 255, 'max_recordset_name_length': 255, 'max_page_limit': 1000}


The test logic is based on the actual limit numbers received for a project (primary), so if the limit number of characters received from the Designate was 63, then the test would try using: 62 (expected PASS) and 63 (expected: FAIL) accordingly.

My point on these to tests is that it's not getting to the 255 character check, because it is failing the 63 character, per label, check first.

I.e. <label up to 63 chars>.<label up to 63 chars>.<label up to 63 chars>.... cannot exceed 255.
Same issue here, the label is too long and you are getting a correct error before it gets to the recordset name check.

From a jammy image build log:

 2023-02-02 01:49:57.848 | dib-run-parts Running /tmp/in_target.d/install.d/10-pip-packages
 2023-02-02 01:49:57.855 | + set -e
 2023-02-02 01:49:57.855 | + '[' -z ']'
 2023-02-02 01:49:57.855 | + exit 0
 2023-02-02 01:49:57.857 | dib-run-parts 10-pip-packages completed
 
This file can safely be removed.

We do appear to actually install this tox-env and put tox in it looking at a jammy image build. I suspect that we were thinking we could set the ensure-tox var to find tox at this path and avoid some job runtime overhead. Considering we haven't been doing that removing this file isn't a regression.

We might want to consider doing that to speed up jobs. However, with all the tox upgrade madness I kinda like managing tox at runtime as it is more flexible.
Yeah, I think this was the idea.  But I can not see that a global tox install is going to be good for anything now, given version skews, jobs not even using tox, etc.
